I.  THE ONGOING PROJECT 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Microfinance Risk Participation and Guarantee 
Program (MFP) is the on-going project in the context of the proposed technical assistance (TA). 
The MFP is a credit enhancement program designed to address market gaps by sharing risks to 
facilitate local currency lending to microfinance institutions (MFIs) for on-lending to low-income 
borrowers, predominantly women. With a program limit of $600 million that is operationalized on 
a revolving basis, the MFP has supported $1.8 billion in new local currency loans since its 
inception, benefiting more than 8 million borrowers across ADB’s developing member countries 
(DMCs).1 
 
2.  Over the years, the MFP has expanded its scope and coverage and aims to build micro-
finance and related insurance, as a means to build climate change resilience. While traditionally 
microfinance has been limited to collateral-free loans for the poor and gradually extended to 
include savings, it is now a well-regulated and mature business in many markets and is being 
viewed as a comprehensive platform to deliver banking and financial security to the poor.2 One 
of the emerging roles is its linkages with the climate change and disaster vulnerable population, 
a large proportion of which are in rural and peri-urban dwellings and derive their livelihoods from 
agriculture and related activities. Across ADB’s DMCs, MFIs have made a significant contribution 
in supporting the income streams and livelihoods of their borrowing clients and have helped 
improve livelihoods. In the process, MFIs also build very strong linkages and social capital with 
the communities they serve.  
 
3.  However, in times of disaster and in the post-disaster recovery phase, when the impacted 
population is in critical need of funds to meet basic needs and re-start their livelihoods, MFIs often 
find themselves facing financial challenges related to their loan portfolio-distress, pressure on 
their capital and liquidity, and an inability to raise funds for on-lending.3 The MFIs’ inability to 
respond to these disaster-linked exigencies is closely linked to the lack of microinsurance 
coverage for the micro-borrowers. If there was microinsurance cover in place, the impacted 
families would be better placed to allocate the claims and their savings back into income-
generating livelihoods, restoration of their homes and keeping their children in school. The climate 
change and disaster induced distress also results in severe deterioration in the micro-borrower's 
ability to service the loans taken from the MFIs, as their income streams and livelihoods are 
adversely impacted. The lack of risk-coverage or insurance and the associated inability to access 
finance,  results  in  a  prolonged  post-calamity  recovery  often  characterized  with  regional 
displacement  of  the  earning  population,  social  unrest  and  distress-sale  of  the  recovered 
household assets/savings, which further undermines the creditworthiness of micro-borrowers. 
While government and state-owned agencies step-up their work, their support is focused on 
disaster-relief, rather than restoring livelihoods and income for post-disaster recovery. 
 
 
1  Of the $600 million limit, $260 million is for MFP’s COVID-19 response which has an initial validity of 15 months (April

II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
4.  Climate Change and Impact on the Poor. While climate change impacts all, the effects are 
hitting the world’s poorest people, (such as small holder farmers) first and in the most severe 
manner. Many are pushed back into poverty or their path to improved livelihoods and a better 
quality of life is substantially extended. Given their already fragile state, it is harder for the poor to 
recover from droughts, hurricanes, storms and floods, leaving behind failed harvests, flood-
ravaged fields, destroyed agriculture-related income sources like cattle, damaged homes, and the 
health crises that often occur in the wake of a disaster.4 While their access to finance is already 
limited, this worsens in the post-disaster stage and substantially raises the challenges to cope 
and adapt to the calamity and draw a path to restoring their livelihoods and re-building dwellings. 
This lack of access to finance in the post-calamity stage results in a prolonged recovery and is 
often accompanied by distress sale of assets by households (HH). Many who live on the margins 
of poverty slip back into real poverty.5 It has been estimated that by 2030, climate change could 
push more than 120 million more people into poverty.6 
 
5.  Impact of Climate Change and Disasters on Women.  Women and particularly small holder 
farmers amongst them, are more disadvantaged in facing the impacts of climate change, as they 
have lesser access to resources, credit, agricultural inputs, technology, training and extension 
services, as compared to men. Since women often have less than proportionate participation in 
decision-making and are not equally involved in the distribution of environment management 
benefits, they are less able to manage the climate change related adversities.7 Climate change is 
making it harder for women to carry out household responsibilities.8Further, poor households 
which suffer from climate-related hazards and disasters may adopt extreme coping actions that 
can lead to “long-term and intergenerational vulnerability, such as early marriage for girls, selling 
land and other assets for less than their value, withdrawing children from school, and reducing 
their food consumption”. Depending on the severity of the crises, some of these adverse impacts 
may well be of intergenerational proportions.9 In this context, adopting measures that specifically 
focus on women and help to bring a gender-development aspect to climate change mitigation and 
disaster-mitigation responses, have a special position and role in ADB’s NSO operations. The 
MFP, which deepens access to finance for women micro-borrowers, is a robust platform in 
PSOD’s operations to help connect and strengthen these linkages.

6.  Role of Financial Sector Interventions in Building Climate Change and Disaster Resilience. 
Through the past decade, planning and programming to strengthen climate change resilience is 
now a mainstream activity in development work and it is also rapidly evolving as a focus area in 
financial sector interventions. Governments and donors are prioritizing integrated disaster risk 
management (DRM) approaches that shift support away from reactionary crisis management; 
towards prevention and early action, like setting up ex-ante risk financing structures.10 As a part 
of  these  efforts,  microinsurance  has  been  identified  as  a  tool  that  can  protect  vulnerable 
populations from climate change induced shocks by acting as a safety net and buffer for their 
income and assets against extreme weather events.  
 
7.  While the conceptual knowledge for microinsurance has expanded, there is limited but 
steadily expanding empirical work done to pilot test and commercialize a climate change and 
disaster risk-coverage insurance product in the DMCs. In addition, while there are several state-
initiated activities, the role of private sector insurance providers has been limited. The existing 
work in this and related fields, focuses more on activities like crop insurance, a state supported 
activity, often surrounded with several risk coverage and implementation challenges.11 Given the 
extremely low insurance penetration levels in Asian countries, with 85% of assets12 and nearly 
90% of the populations uninsured13, rigorous assessments of the operational challenges, best-
practices and success of climate risk focused microinsurance, particularly for the poor, are 
relatively few and far between. The proposed TA aims to address this gap by supporting the pilot 
testing of a parametric insurance product for micro-borrowers in India. The lessons learned from 
the pilot testing and implementation would be (i) critical inputs in the design and roll-out of a 
commercial scale parametric insurance product, which has not yet been mainstreamed at a 
commercial scale in India and for most DMCs and (ii) shared within the regional DMCs, for 
development of their insurance and micro-finance sectors.  
 
8.  TA’s Linkages with PSOD’s Microfinance Program. Since its inception, the MFP has 
worked with more than 30 MFIs in India and in the region, which have been selected after a 
rigorous assessment of their operations, financial and overall credit-standing. Several of these 
partner MFIs in ADB’s MFP are now strongly positioned in terms of (i) their wide geographic 
coverage in India/host country market, (ii) vast physical and social infrastructure and linkages with 
rural households, specifically women which account for 98% of their client base, (iii) adoption of 
client protection principles and fair lending practices in operations to safeguard the interests of 
their borrowers, and (iv) rigorous operational and risk oversight processes embedded in their 
progressively digitalized microfinance model. These attributes are critical in developing and pilot 
testing a parametric microinsurance product, which is targeted at the lower income vulnerable 
sections of the DMC’s population, which is also the key target client base of such well-functioning 
MFIs. 
 
9.  The MFP is very well placed to build on the synergies and utilize the well-established 
network linkages built under the program for implementation of the TA. The MFP has been 
working with the prominent MFIs (which serve nearly 70% of the microfinance market in India), 
as well as in other targeted DMCs like Bangladesh and Indonesia (and soon to include Cambodia 
and Philippines). The MFP also works closely with the country-level microfinance associations on 
best practice and client-centric approaches to expanding financial inclusion. Given the innovative 
approach in the proposed TA and the scale and operational challenges linked to its pilot-testing,

11.  The main objective of the TA is to support the development and pilot testing of a parametric 
microinsurance product, which will extend risk coverage to the targeted population of low-income 
households in rural areas, whose income and livelihoods are vulnerable to impacts of climate 
change. The developed insurance product would be rolled out for initial pilot testing and eventually 
on a commercial scale by using the physical infrastructure and client linkages built by MFIs and 
these vulnerable households in pre-identified climate-change exposed regions. The pilot test 
would entail coverage in 4 different parts of India which have been identified for their climate 
change and disaster vulnerability, and an outreach to at least more than 3 million potential MFI 
clients through the identified MFIs. The main objectives of the TA are to help develop insurance 
coverage which (a) addresses some of the immediate loss protection that such household would 
need upon a calamity event, and (b) enable post-calamity relief and recovery work by allowing 
access to finance for the impacted population through the partner MFI network. 
 
12.  In this backdrop, the TA support will be routed through to the selected MFIs which will play 
key roles in (a) building basic awareness and enhancing the micro-borrower's understanding of 
parametric insurance by extending their field staff and branch network for the  pilot stage,  
(b) building field-level capacity to allow dissemination of product features, highlighting the costs 
and benefits and claims processes of the insurance policies, and (c) facilitating market testing 
and validation of the insurance product’s acceptability, adoption, and coverage. Later at the 
commercial deployment stage, it is expected that these MFIs will help actively participate in post-
disaster recovery work by expanding access to finance in the impacted regions, given the risk 
mitigation benefit derived from the parametric insurance coverage. 
 
13.  The TA is consistent with ADB’s Strategy 2030 supporting three of its operational priorities: 
addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities, accelerating progress in gender equality 
and tackling climate change and building climate and disaster resilience.  The TA will continue 
ADB’s work to involve women in community-development  and training programs and shaping 
women’s roles, from attendees to decision-makers as micro-insurance enrollees. The TA and the 
microinsurance provides a venue for social protection for rural poor women.  Moreover, the TA 
will potentially help elevate womenfrom poverty and provide a venue for women to participate and 
contribute to economic development.   ADB specifically focuses on addressing the impact climate 
change has on its DMCs and their vulnerable populations, most of whom are dependent on 
agriculture, fisheries and forestry- the same sectors facing high risks from disasters brought about 
by extreme climate events. To better assist member DMCs in sustainably meeting their planned 
growth targets, ADB identifies ‘tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, 
and enhancing environmental sustainability’ as one of its mainstream operational priorities.

Existing Efforts in the Field of Microinsurance:  
 
In many DMCs, the implementation of microinsurance solutions to support climate adaptation has 
been focused on the agriculture sector. Over time, usage of satellite information, risk coverage 
and loss data has been expanding in these initiatives. Illustratively, in 2016, the state government 
of Tamil Nadu, India, introduced RIICE technology along into its new insurance system, serving 
more than one million farmers. Under this insurance system, compensation is more efficient and 
transparent  with  the  use  of  satellite  information,  and  assistance  to  more  farmers  become 
immediate.1 
 
Similarly, the Government of Indonesia developed parametric insurance for climate related risks, 
for  rice  farming.  It  has  been  modernizing  its  rice  cultivation  through  improved  irrigation 
infrastructure and early warning systems, to better cope with droughts and support local farmers. 
Use of parametric insurance has become increasingly available for agriculture assets including 
crops,  livestock,  and  forestry.  The  government  now  employs  regional  drought  indices  and 
provides  province-level  payouts  in  case  of  severe  droughts.2  Similar  initiatives  are  under 
implementation in Bangladesh.  Insurance awareness among the country’s 12 million smallholder 
farmers is being promoted by government and donor agencies.3 There are also some regional 
initiatives, like the Southeast Asia Disaster Risk Insurance Facility (SEADRIF), a catastrophe risk 
pool of funds, designed as a reinsurance-backed disaster liquidity facility with countries making 
upfront payment of contribution/premium. While this is at a national or sovereign level, the main 
advantage is that a country will receive compensatory payouts upon eligible disaster events. 
Signatories to SEADRIF include DMCs like Cambodia, Indonesia, Lao PDR, Myanmar, and 
Philippines.4 
 
Some of gaps in these initiatives evidently are: (a) they are generally state sponsored, hence 
commercial viability is not specifically targeted; (b) while they cover an important segment of crop-
cultivation related risks, there is no specific coverage for general non-farming rural households 
(like the landless farm laborers), or for other climate-change adversities which impact several 
other parts of rural livelihoods; (c) there is limited engagement of the private sector or an effort to 
develop a wider-scale insurance product which will cover a wider array of climate change-induced 
adversities and risks. Currently, there is no appropriate product to provide insurance against such 
events, nor a capacity-building initiative, to develop and roll this out on commercial standards, 
though some instruments do exist for specific parameters.
